SENT.plain: Marfan Syndrome (MFS) is a genetic disorder of the connective tissue with multisystemic manifestations, which typically involves the skeletal, cardiovascular and ocular systems
It is usually associated with fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene mutations, an extracellular matrix protein, and its diagnosi requires the presence of several clinical criteria, called the Ghent criteria

Studies with animal models have helped understand some of the pathophysiologic mechanisms of the syndrome, and the core role of transforming growth factor, (TGF-beta) signalling pathways in these mutations
These findings created new therapeutic opportunities, like the use of losartan, known to have an antagonistic effect on TGF-beta
With the aging of this population, new clinical manifestations are expected, requiring close and continued MFS patient monitoring
